items.content_html:
In line with what others are doing, I'm sorting all JS pages under guide/reference.

Note that JS docs call guide "guide" and not "guides", which I think makes more sense because it's a single, coherent book (like "Learn") as opposed to a collection of pages by topic.

Note also that I'm putting a few pages under "reference" because they introduce concepts unseen elsewhere and are specified separately in the specification. In particular I'm rebranding the "event loop" page to "execution model", which I've been meaning to do for a long time, because that unlocks ways to significantly expand it, in order to eventually work on #5006.
items.title: Put all JS pages under guide/reference

items.content_html:
moved 3 guides up a level.
moved context examples under context guide

this is a 2 part PR. First moving the files; after this is merged, I will update them. Too many changes to do both in one PR.
items.title: Move z-index guides to be directly under module

items.content_html:
Description

Chrome 134 supports customizable <select> elements (see https://chromestatus.com/feature/5737365999976448).

This includes a multitude of sub-features, which are as follows:

  • The <selectedcontent> element, which under the hood provides a <slot> into which is placed the contents of the currently-selected <option>. This is the content visible inside the closed <select> element, otherwise known as the select <button>.
  • The ::picker(select) pseudo-element, which targets the entire contents of the select drop-down menu, otherwise known as the picker.
  • The appearance property value base-select, which opts the <select> element and the ::picker(select) pseudo-element into the browser-defined default styles and behavior for customizable select.
  • The :open pseudo-class, which can now target the select <button> when the picker (::picker(select)) is open.
  • The ::picker-icon pseudo-element, which targets the picker icon inside the select <button> â€” the little down-facing arrow on the inline-end side.
  • The :checked pseudo-class, which can now target the currently-selected <option> element.
  • The ::checkmark pseudo-element, which targets the checkmark placed inside the currently-selected <option> element to provide a visual indication of which one is selected.

In addition, the select <button> and the picker have the following behavior assigned to them automatically:

  • They have an invoker/popover relationship, as specified by the Popover API.
  • They have an implicit anchor reference, meaning that the picker is automatically positioned relative to the select <button> via CSS anchor positioning.

This PR aims to document all of the above new/updated features, and provide a guide to creating customizable <select>s.

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests

Fixes #37857.
items.title: Document customizable <select> elements

items.content_html:
Description

A response to the dev-doc-needed request on Bug 1709652 "Webextension i18n not using intl.locale.requested". The changes originally flagged weren't required (video and reference to UI update had been previously removed). However, the notes made reference to the need to restart an extension after changing the UI language, which wasn't previously documented. Tested and confirmed before updating.
items.title: Bug 1709652 clarify need to restart extension when testing localization
add a link

items.content_html:
Description

Addresses the dev-docs-needed requirements of Bug 1753501 "More documentation for developers about null returns in proxy.onRequest listeners" by adding the information that including a null return or array of objects ending in a null prevents fail over to the browser defined proxy.
items.title: Bug 1753501 null returns in proxy.onRequest listeners explained

items.content_html:
Description

For manifest V3, the developer must come up with an ID on their own to submit the extension. I clarified it (I think in the best location) and provided details on the requirements and how to to choose one.

Motivation

AFAICT nowhere in the docs did it say that the developer can come up with the extension ID on their own, and in several places it's suggested that they don't come up with it on their own (ex: testing locally, uploading manifest V2 extensions with no ID).

This confused me for several hours until I joined the addons web chat and got an answer from someone official.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Clarify extension ID creation

items.content_html:
Description

The Optional bfcache NotRestoredReasons were standardized in whatwg/html#10154 and will be included in Chrome 135.

Motivation

Remove one reason that will no longer be used, and make clear there is a specific set of reasons that are now standardized.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Update optional NotRestoredReasons

items.content_html:
FF137 is adding deprecation warnings for Document.afterscriptexecute event, Document.beforescriptexecute event, Element.afterscriptexecute event, and Element.beforescriptexecute event, in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1949373

This is part of a usage test, on the way to unimplementation in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1584269

This PR adds a release note about the deprecation, because we'd like people to know they should start not using it.
items.title: FF137 Relnote: beforescriptexecution and afterscript execution events deprecated

items.content_html:
Description

Also link to the imperative equivalent of the various built-in commands.

Motivation

It'll help readers understand which commands are available.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests

Relates to #38322

Depends on: mdn/browser-compat-data#26105
items.title: Add documentation for request-close invoker command

items.content_html:
Description

Addresses the dev-docs-needed request for Bug 1636751 "proxy.onRequest return with proxyAuthorizationHeader not proxying the request" by clarifying that only HTTPS proxies can be specified.
items.title: Bug-1636751 proxy.onRequest with proxyAuthorizationHeader HTTPS only

Related issues and pull requests

items.title: Bug-1659500 contextualIdentities API undefined in Firefox for Android

items.content_html:
Description

Chrome 132 supports a new option, usage, in the descriptor of the GPUTexture.createView() method. This allows you to limit the view usage to a subset of the usages set on the source texture.

See https://developer.chrome.com/blog/new-in-webgpu-132#texture_view_usage and https://chromestatus.com/feature/5155252832305152 for more information.

This PR documents the new option.

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests

Fixes #38360
items.title: Editorial review: Add docs for GPUTexture.createView() usage option

items.content_html:
Description

Originally, when we published our FileSystemObserver docs, we linked to a complete demo that was published on Glitch. However, it is more convenient to host full demos on the dom-examples repo because the code is easier to maintain.

We checked that the licensing situation was compatible and then created a copy of the demo on dom-examples.

This PR updates the links in the docs to that example and its source code to link to the dom-examples version rather than glitch.

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Update FileSystemObserver links to point to dom-examples
